post_body_text: Electric vehicles are crucial to reducing emissions. To meet the projected demand, the world is going to need more precious metals. Escaid portfolio of diluents has been specifically designed for use in the solvent extraction process of rare earth and precious metals. Watch the video to discover how Escaid diluents help efficient, effective and safe solvent extraction for mining processes. Learn more: https://www.exxonmobilchemical.com/en/resources/library/library-detail/111813/escaid_miners_version_sub_en?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=fluids_escaid&utm_content=111814

post_body_text: 🆕 We’re excited to announce Dina Powell McCormick will join our Board of Directors effective January 1st. Dina is currently vice chairman and president of Global Client Services at BDT & MSD Partners, an investment and advisory firm, and previously spent 16 years at The Goldman Sachs Group Inc. “Dina is a distinguished executive with a rare level of geopolitical, national security and economic experience,” ExxonMobil Chairman and CEO Darren Woods said. “She has served two U.S presidents in diplomatic and national security roles and, more recently, led Goldman Sachs’ sustainability efforts, a useful combination of experiences for the ExxonMobil boardroom.” Welcome Dina to the ExxonMobil Board of Directors. 🎉 Learn more: https://exxonmobil.co/462JynJ

post_body_text: “The energy transition is a global challenge – it’s not one size fits all.” Those are the words of Matt Crocker, senior vice president for our Low Carbon Solutions business, at a recent Houston Asia Society event, where he shared our plan to help accelerate the world’s path to net zero emissions. We’re starting with the technologies that match our strengths -- carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and biofuels. We have agreements in place to transport and store up to 5 million metric tons of CO₂ a year for three of our customers along the U.S. Gulf Coast. That’s equivalent to replacing approximately 2 million gasoline-powered cars with electric vehicles, which is roughly equal to the total number of EVs on US roads today. We’re also planning to build the world’s largest low-carbon hydrogen plant in Baytown, Texas, at planned start up. We plan to invest $17 billion through 2027 on lower-emission initiatives. Matt shared the stage with Takajiro “Tak” Ishikawa, president and CEO of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) America. ExxonMobil and MHI have a strategic alliance on #carboncapture technology. They discussed the value of working with start-ups on cutting-edge technology, the need for creative solutions in countries that lack geologic formations for CO₂ storage, and the growing demand from industries seeking help to reduce their emissions. The panel also included Charles McConnell, executive director of carbon management and energy sustainability at the University of Houston and Uday Turaga, CEO of ADI Analytics. Learn more about how we’re scaling solutions for industry: https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/delivering-industrial-solutions/carbon-capture-and-storage/lcs-highlights-new-technologies-on-energy-podcast #XOM #exxonmobil #carboncapture

post_body_text: Diversify. That’s the typical advice you get from a financial advisor. But that’s also the advice we’d give you to ensure energy security. Why? It’s a strong defense against: 🚢 supply disruption 🛍️ volatility caused by geo-political turmoil 💰 higher energy cost In order to maintain energy security without increasing global emissions, energy diversification should be a priority for nations worldwide. That’s the message from our very own Peter Clarke, senior VP of global LNG, when he spoke at Gastech Exhibition & Conference in Singapore earlier this month. At ExxonMobil, we offer diverse, flexible, reliable and lower-carbon LNG from our global portfolio. Diversification is what we deliver. Learn more here: https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/diversity-of-supply#%E2%80%9CDiversify%E2%80%9D

post_body_text: ExxonMobil and Toyota USA have been working together for decades, developing performance technology for drivers – both on and off the racetrack. So, when the World Rally Championship announced a mandatory switch to biofuels, TOYOTA GAZOO Racing WRC needed our help to recalibrate its cars to meet new requirements – and fast. The season was just around the bend. The result: a winning formula. Specifically, a new Mobil 1 lubricant for the racing team’s existing engines that matched the racing team’s needs, while maintaining a high level of power and efficiency. Toyota Gazoo Racing was a triple title winner in last season’s FIA World Rally Championship (Manufacturers’, Drivers’, and Co-Drivers’ Champions). Here’s how we got the job done, in record time. https://exxonmobil.co/3ZhQpI9

post_body_text: Hydrogen is the most abundant element on earth. And because hydrogen fuel is versatile and produces no emissions at point-of-use (only water vapor), hydrogen can play a big role helping society meet its net-zero goals. Our planned hydrogen facility in Baytown, TX, will produce 1 billion cubic feet of hydrogen per day, helping decarbonize processes in heavy-emitting sectors and reducing our own CO₂ emissions, too. 3 reasons hydrogen is so promising: 🧑‍🔬 It can have a significant impact. We predict its use at Baytown could reduce site-wide CO₂ emissions by up to 30% compared to current operations. ⚡️ It can power activities too remote or energy intensive for electrification, like maritime shipping or high-heat applications. 🔵 It has a lower lifecycle carbon footprint than natural gas when produced with carbon capture and storage (CCS). What’s good for industry can also be good for reaching net zero goals🧑‍🔬 🙌 https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/news/viewpoints/low-carbon-hydrogen

post_body_text: Reaching society’s #netzero goals will take all of us. That’s why we’ve joined the Hydrogen Council, a global coalition of industry, governments and investors working to develop hydrogen as part of the #EnergyTransition. “Bringing together global leaders, including governments, industry and investors, fuels the progress and collaboration needed to get society closer to a net zero future,” said Dan Ammann, President of ExxonMobil Low Carbon Solutions. Dan and his Low Carbon Solutions team are planning the world’s largest low-carbon #hydrogen plant here in Texas at planned start-up. We expect it will produce up to 1 billion cubic feet per day of hydrogen, with more than 98% of the associated CO₂ captured and safely stored underground. Learn more about how we’re scaling solutions for industry: https://exxonmobil.co/3N4v6nP #netzero

ExxonMobil’s been capturing CO₂ for more than 30 years. But only our own.
  
 

  In southeast Texas, we’ve broken ground on a new chapter in our #carboncapture leadership: We’ve drilled our first well at a site that could safely store CO₂ emissions for area industries.
  
 

  It’s the latest milestone in our mission to help accelerate society’s path to net zero by scaling up solutions that can make a big difference, such as carbon capture and storage. 
  
 

  To learn more… https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/delivering-industrial-solutions/carbon-capture-and-storage/first-ccs-well

post_body_text:
Did you know the US Gulf Coast is becoming a leader in the effort to scale up CO₂ solutions for industry? We’re making plans to deploy low-carbon hydrogen and carbon capture and storage for multiple Gulf Coast manufacturing sites, including our own: 
  
 

  Near Houston, we’re planning to build the world’s largest low-carbon hydrogen facility at our integrated Baytown complex. More than 98% of the associated CO₂ produced by the facility, or around 7 million metric tons per year, is expected to be captured and permanently stored. 
  
 

  We’ve also agreed to transport and store CO₂ to reduce emissions from Linde plc’s new hydrogen facility in Beaumont, TX; CF Industries’ manufacturing site in Donaldsonville, LA; and Nucor ’s direct reduced iron facility in Convent, LA. 
  
 

  With these three agreements, the total CO₂ we’ve agreed to transport and store for third-party customers has reached 5 million metric tons per year. That’s equivalent to replacing approximately 2 million gasoline-powered cars with electric vehicles, which is roughly equal to the total number of EVs on US roads today.  
  
 

  Get the full story here: https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/delivering-industrial-solutions#Partnershipsandcollaborations
title: NA
content:
Did you know the US Gulf Coast is becoming a leader in the effort to scale up CO₂ solutions for industry?  We’re making plans to deploy low-carbon hydrogen and carbon capture and storage for multiple Gulf Coast manufacturing sites, including our own: 

Near Houston, we’re planning to build the world’s largest low-carbon hydrogen facility at our integrated Baytown complex. More than 98% of the associated CO₂ produced by the facility, or around 7 million metric tons per year, is expected to be captured and permanently stored. 

We’ve also agreed to transport and store CO₂ to reduce emissions from Linde plc’s new hydrogen facility in Beaumont, TX; CF Industries’ manufacturing site in Donaldsonville, LA; and Nucor ’s direct reduced iron facility in Convent, LA. 

With these three agreements, the total CO₂ we’ve agreed to transport and store for third-party customers has reached 5 million metric tons per year. That’s equivalent to replacing approximately 2 million gasoline-powered cars with electric vehicles, which is roughly equal to the total number of EVs on US roads today.  

Get the full story here: https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/delivering-industrial-solutions#Partnershipsandcollaborations

post_body_text:
“The energy transition is a global challenge – it’s not one size fits all.”
  
 

  Those are the words of Matt Crocker, senior vice president for our Low Carbon Solutions business, at a recent Houston Asia Society event, where he shared our plan to help accelerate the world’s path to net zero emissions. We’re starting with the technologies that match our strengths -- carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and biofuels.
  
 

  We have agreements in place to transport and store up to 5 million metric tons of CO₂ a year for three of our customers along the U.S. Gulf Coast. That’s equivalent to replacing approximately 2 million gasoline-powered cars with electric vehicles, which is roughly equal to the total number of EVs on US roads today. We’re also planning to build the world’s largest low-carbon hydrogen plant in Baytown, Texas, at planned start up.
  
 

  We plan to invest $17 billion through 2027 on lower-emission initiatives. 
  
 

  Matt shared the stage with Takajiro “Tak” Ishikawa, president and CEO of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) America. ExxonMobil and MHI have a strategic alliance on #carboncapture technology. 
  
 

  They discussed the value of working with start-ups on cutting-edge technology, the need for creative solutions in countries that lack geologic formations for CO₂ storage, and the growing demand from industries seeking help to reduce their emissions. 
  
 

  The panel also included Charles McConnell, executive director of carbon management and energy sustainability at the University of Houston and Uday Turaga, CEO of ADI Analytics.
  
 

  Learn more about how we’re scaling solutions for industry: https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/delivering-industrial-solutions/carbon-capture-and-storage/lcs-highlights-new-technologies-on-energy-podcast
  
 

  #XOM #exxonmobil #carboncapture
title: NA
content:
“The energy transition is a global challenge – it’s not one size fits all.”

Those are the words of Matt Crocker, senior vice president for our Low Carbon Solutions business, at a recent Houston Asia Society event, where he shared our plan to help accelerate the world’s path to net zero emissions. We’re starting with the technologies that match our strengths -- carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and biofuels.

We have agreements in place to transport and store up to 5 million metric tons of CO₂ a year for three of our customers along the U.S. Gulf Coast. That’s equivalent to replacing approximately 2 million gasoline-powered cars with electric vehicles, which is roughly equal to the total number of EVs on US roads today. We’re also planning to build the world’s largest low-carbon hydrogen plant in Baytown, Texas, at planned start up.

We plan to invest $17 billion through 2027 on lower-emission initiatives. 

Matt shared the stage with Takajiro “Tak” Ishikawa, president and CEO of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) America. ExxonMobil and MHI have a strategic alliance on #carboncapture technology. 

They discussed the value of working with start-ups on cutting-edge technology, the need for creative solutions in countries that lack geologic formations for CO₂ storage, and the growing demand from industries seeking help to reduce their emissions. 

The panel also included Charles McConnell, executive director of carbon management and energy sustainability at the University of Houston and Uday Turaga, CEO of ADI Analytics.

Learn more about how we’re scaling solutions for industry: https://corporate.exxonmobil.com/what-we-do/delivering-industrial-solutions/carbon-capture-and-storage/lcs-highlights-new-technologies-on-energy-podcast

post_body_text:
ExxonMobil and Toyota USA have been working together for decades, developing performance technology for drivers – both on and off the racetrack. So, when the World Rally Championship announced a mandatory switch to biofuels, TOYOTA GAZOO Racing WRC needed our help to recalibrate its cars to meet new requirements – and fast. The season was just around the bend.
  
 

  The result: a winning formula. Specifically, a new Mobil 1 lubricant for the racing team’s existing engines that matched the racing team’s needs, while maintaining a high level of power and efficiency. Toyota Gazoo Racing was a triple title winner in last season’s FIA World Rally Championship (Manufacturers’, Drivers’, and Co-Drivers’ Champions).
  
 

  Here’s how we got the job done, in record time. 
  
 

  https://exxonmobil.co/3ZhQpI9
title: NA
content:
ExxonMobil and Toyota USA have been working together for decades, developing performance technology for drivers – both on and off the racetrack. So, when the World Rally Championship announced a mandatory switch to biofuels, TOYOTA GAZOO Racing WRC needed our help to recalibrate its cars to meet new requirements – and fast. The season was just around the bend.

The result: a winning formula. Specifically, a new Mobil 1 lubricant for the racing team’s existing engines that matched the racing team’s needs, while maintaining a high level of power and efficiency. Toyota Gazoo Racing was a triple title winner in last season’s FIA World Rally Championship (Manufacturers’, Drivers’, and Co-Drivers’ Champions).

Here’s how we got the job done, in record time. 

https://exxonmobil.co/3ZhQpI9

post_body_text:
We’re helping accelerate the world’s path to net zero emissions. How? By scaling up solutions like #carboncapture, #hydrogen, and #biofuels. 
  
 

  Check out our webcast to hear Dan Ammann, president of our Low Carbon Solutions business, talk about our big ambitions for our low-carbon products and services, which can significantly reduce CO2 emissions from sectors like heavy industry (like steel, cement and chemicals), power generation and commercial transportation (trucks, ships and planes).
  
 

  How much can be abated? Current planned projects would remove about 20 million metric tons of CO2 a year for our customers, equal to replacing 7 million gasoline-powered cars with electric vehicles in the United States*. These include our new hydrogen plant in Baytown, Texas; our carbon capture and storage projects along the U.S. Gulf Coast; and our biofuels project at Imperial’s Strathcona refinery in Canada. 
  
 

  “We’re intensely focused on helping to accelerate the world’s path to net zero by making that path economically viable and making it executable at a scale that matters,” Ammann said. 
  
 

  Our Chairman and CEO Darren Woods said ExxonMobil is has the scale, integration, technology, and people to create impactful, economically viable solutions in pursuit of net zero.  
  
 

  Click here to read more about how ExxonMobil is helping reduce emissions from key industries.
  
 

  * CO2 emissions figures are estimates only; actual reductions may vary. Projects (including the Baytown hydrogen project) are at various stages of maturity and remain subject to final investment decision by the corporation.
  
 

  https://exxonmobil.co/3ZHjTxy

Heavy industry, like manufacturing, steel, cement and power generation, has historically come with heavy emissions.

post_body_text:
🔨🏗️ Construction moves forward on the largest renewable diesel facility in Canada. The Strathcona facility received a $560M investment from our majority-owned affiliate Imperial Oil today. With expected start-up in 2025, the Strathcona facility will: 
  
 

  🛢️ Produce up to 20K barrels of renewable diesel a day primarily from locally sourced feedstocks
  
 

  ⚡ Use low-carbon hydrogen with #carboncapture and storage technology
  
 

  👷 ~600 direct construction jobs, along with hundreds more by business partners
  
 

  “The Strathcona project is another example of how we are investing in advantaged facilities and applying our leading technology and decades of experience to develop lower-emission solutions for customers,” said Karen McKee, president of ExxonMobil Product Solutions. “We continue to focus investments on markets like Canada, where well-designed policies support technologies that reduce life cycle emissions.”
  
 

  The facility is a part of our plans through 2027 to invest ~$17 billion in lower-emission initiatives.
  
 

  Read more: https://exxonmobil.co/3XH4JIG

post_body_text:
We‘re investing in and producing more oil and gas than any other U.S. energy company while also investing in initiatives to reduce GHG emissions for our own operations – and providing solutions to help our customers reduce theirs. 
  
 

  Specific to refining capacity in the U.S., we invested through the downturn so we could increase refining capacity to process light crude by about 250,000 barrels per day – the equivalent of adding a new medium-sized refinery to our operations. We kept investing, even during the pandemic, when we lost more than $20 billion and had to borrow more than $30 billion to maintain our investment and be ready for the post-pandemic demand. 
  
 

  Learn more at https://exxonmobil.co/3IKQNbQ.
  
 

  #SOAE2023

post_body_text:
We achieved another incredible milestone in 2023, marking a decade of partnership with the Port Moresby Nature Park.
  
 

  Our support extends beyond mere funding and represents ExxonMobil’s commitment to seeing the Nature Park reach its full potential for the benefit of the wider community and the preservation of Papua New Guinea’s amazing and diverse biodiversity.
  
  Since 2013, our annual grants have not only helped transform the physical landscape of the Nature Park and its exhibits, but it has enabled vital research and conservation activities to be carried out.
  
  More than 125,000 National Capital District and Central Province school children have participated in the award-winning school education program, while through the Breed-for-Release program, almost 50 endangered Native Pig-Nosed Turtle, or Piku, hatchlings have been transported from the Kikori Delta to the Port Moresby Nature Park for lifecycle research. Once fully grown, turtles are returned to the wild to improve their chances of survival. This program has also supported other wildlife including Tree Kangaroos, Birds-of-Paradise, and Frogs.
  
  Our IT Department also provides ongoing support through donations of equipment, including more than 35 computers and a dedicated server to store complex programs that run ticketing, bookings, memberships, accounting, payroll, inventory, and wildlife management software.
  
  Thank you to our yellow army of staff volunteers who have joined our business in supporting the Nature Park and over the years have played a part in shaping the stories, memories, and experiences of those that have walked through its gates.
  
  This past decade is only the beginning, and we can’t wait to see what we can achieve over the next decade together. #PNGLNG #PNGpartnership
title: NA
content:
We achieved another incredible milestone in 2023, marking a decade of partnership with the Port Moresby Nature Park.

Our support extends beyond mere funding and represents ExxonMobil’s commitment to seeing the Nature Park reach its full potential for the benefit of the wider community and the preservation of Papua New Guinea’s amazing and diverse biodiversity.
 
Since 2013, our annual grants have not only helped transform the physical landscape of the Nature Park and its exhibits, but it has enabled vital research and conservation activities to be carried out.
 
More than 125,000 National Capital District and Central Province school children have participated in the award-winning school education program, while through the Breed-for-Release program, almost 50 endangered Native Pig-Nosed Turtle, or Piku, hatchlings have been transported from the Kikori Delta to the Port Moresby Nature Park for lifecycle research. Once fully grown, turtles are returned to the wild to improve their chances of survival. This program has also supported other wildlife including Tree Kangaroos, Birds-of-Paradise, and Frogs.
 
Our IT Department also provides ongoing support through donations of equipment, including more than 35 computers and a dedicated server to store complex programs that run ticketing, bookings, memberships, accounting, payroll, inventory, and wildlife management software.
 
Thank you to our yellow army of staff volunteers who have joined our business in supporting the Nature Park and over the years have played a part in shaping the stories, memories, and experiences of those that have walked through its gates.
 
This past decade is only the beginning, and we can’t wait to see what we can achieve over the next decade together. #PNGLNG #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
This week we were proud to be a Principal Premium sponsor of the 17th PNG Chamber of Resources & Energy Investment Conference and Exhibition in Sydney, Australia. 
  
  In her address to delegates, our Chairperson and Managing Director, Tera Shandro, mapped out the future of Papua New Guinea’s resource opportunities and reinforced the growing importance of #LNG towards the security of supply, and the energy transition.
  
  “As the world’s population increases, so too does its need for affordable, secure, and reliable energy, with improved emissions intensity compared to legacy sources,” Ms Shandro said.
  
  “Natural gas, and particularly LNG, will play a vital role in meeting this demand and support climate goals, as it emits up to 60 percent fewer greenhouse gases and significantly fewer air pollutants when compared with traditional energy sources. With 40 percent of the world’s electricity still being generated by coal, there are many opportunities for meaningful emissions reductions by making the switch to natural gas, and that’s why it sits at the center of our strategy.
  
  “From ExxonMobil’s perspective, Asia Pacific countries are expected to be a core natural gas customer for decades to come and will continue turning to Papua New Guinea thanks to its proximity, high quality resources and efficient and reliable operating facilities.
  
  “#PNGLNG is already leading the world in energy emissions intensity and reliability, but as we look to our latest investment, the Papua LNG Project alongside TotalEnergies, its proposed plans are an example of how new technology applied to proven processes, such as electric trains, can help provide affordable energy in a lower-carbon world.
  
  “In addition to this, ExxonMobil also has interest in P’nyang LNG, as we as well as significant exploration activity across Papua New Guinea including the Wildebeest prospect. If all these potential projects were to progresses, not only does it mean over a decade of construction activity, but it also means Papua New Guinea’s role as an energy supplier extends beyond 2050,” Ms Shandro concluded.
  
  Thank you to delegates who visited our team at the ExxonMobil PNG booth and our partners for your continued collaboration. #PNGpartnership #pngcoreinvestmentconference2023
title: NA
content:
This week we were proud to be a Principal Premium sponsor of the 17th PNG Chamber of Resources & Energy Investment Conference and Exhibition in Sydney, Australia. 
 
In her address to delegates, our Chairperson and Managing Director, Tera Shandro, mapped out the future of Papua New Guinea’s resource opportunities and reinforced the growing importance of #LNG towards the security of supply, and the energy transition.
 
“As the world’s population increases, so too does its need for affordable, secure, and reliable energy, with improved emissions intensity compared to legacy sources,” Ms Shandro said.
 
“Natural gas, and particularly LNG, will play a vital role in meeting this demand and support climate goals, as it emits up to 60 percent fewer greenhouse gases and significantly fewer air pollutants when compared with traditional energy sources. With 40 percent of the world’s electricity still being generated by coal, there are many opportunities for meaningful emissions reductions by making the switch to natural gas, and that’s why it sits at the center of our strategy.
 
“From ExxonMobil’s perspective, Asia Pacific countries are expected to be a core natural gas customer for decades to come and will continue turning to Papua New Guinea thanks to its proximity, high quality resources and efficient and reliable operating facilities.
 
“#PNGLNG is already leading the world in energy emissions intensity and reliability, but as we look to our latest investment, the Papua LNG Project alongside TotalEnergies, its proposed plans are an example of how new technology applied to proven processes, such as electric trains, can help provide affordable energy in a lower-carbon world.
 
“In addition to this, ExxonMobil also has interest in P’nyang LNG, as we as well as significant exploration activity across Papua New Guinea including the Wildebeest prospect. If all these potential projects were to progresses, not only does it mean over a decade of construction activity, but it also means Papua New Guinea’s role as an energy supplier extends beyond 2050,” Ms Shandro concluded.
 
Thank you to delegates who visited our team at the ExxonMobil PNG booth and our partners for your continued collaboration. #PNGpartnership #pngcoreinvestmentconference2023
bio: ExxonMobil PNG, Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. 24,199 likes · 85 talking about this. Energy Company

post_body_text:
At the invitation of Wapu Sonk, Managing Director at Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited, Peter Clarke, Senior Vice President - Global LNG for ExxonMobil, joined the Prime Minister, Honourable James Marape, and Minister for Petroleum and Energy, Honourable Kerenga Kua, onstage to open the Petroleum & Energy Conference Papua New Guinea held at the Hilton Hotel.
  
 

  In his keynote industry address, Mr Clarke discussed the important role that #LNG and Papua New Guinea can play in the world’s energy future. 
  
 

  “More than ever, there is recognition that natural gas, and in particular LNG, will play a vital role in meeting growing demand for energy, while reducing overall emission to support climate goals.
  
 

  "With proximity to market and high-quality resources, Papua New Guinea is well positioned to continue supporting regional demand, with Asia Pacific countries set to be core natural gas customers for decades to come,” Mr Clarke said. #PNGpartnership #PNGLNG

  To mark the fifth year of ExxonMobil’s #PowerPlayAwards, we are launching Power Play Awards Papua New Guinea to highlight the accomplishments of the exceptional women, and the men who support them, across Papua New Guinea‘s LNG industry.
  
 

  This award is about celebrating and recognising the contributions that all levels of government, local businesses, project partners, and the diverse landowner communities make to the LNG industry in Papua New Guinea.
  
  Submission of nominations are now open and will close on Thursday 20 April.
  
  For eligibility requirements and information on how to nominate a candidate or more details on Power Play Awards Papua New Guinea visit: https://pnglng.com/Community/Power-Play-Awards-Papua-New-Guinea #WomeninLNG #DiversityinLNG

transcript_text: Get ready, Papua New Guinea, the Powerplay Awards are here. Powerplay has been developed by leading women across ExxonMobil, specifically for women in the LNG industry, bringing them together to network, collaborate and do business. And in the spirit of its fifth year, we're launching Powerplay Awards right here in Papua New Guinea. This is not just another awards program. It's a recognition program that seeks to acknowledge every nomination for their contributions to the LNG industry in PNG and identify the best of the best in each of the three Powerplay Award categories. Do you know the next rising star? Could it be you? This first category will honour an outstanding woman under the age of 35 who is excelling in the early stages of the LNG career. A you or your colleague, a pioneer of business, innovation or technology. This second category will honour a woman who has delivered outstanding business results or innovation and technology leadership amid the ever evolving energy transition landscape. Thus being an ambassador by leading and uplifting fellow peers, some like you or someone you know, this third category will honour a proper New Guinea who threw their wets, actions and positive energy, inspires those who work with and around them. Enter today, nominations are now open for the Powerplay Awards' company. From business support to technical, to catering, labour hire and more. If you want to hear your stories of accomplishment and success. Come on, Powerplay Guinea. Let's celebrate the women who are transforming the LNG industry, just like it has transformed our lives.

post_body_text:
Over the past century PNG has proven to be a good place to invest and at ExxonMobil PNG we are confident it will remain so going forward.
  
  This was the message Peter Larden, Chairman and Managing Director at ExxonMobil PNG, shared with delegates at the 16th PNG Chamber of Mines and Petroleum Investment Conference and Exhibition in Sydney, Australia.
  
  Peter joined fellow panelists, the Honourable Richard Maru, Minister for International Trade and Investment, and Honourable Julie Bishop, former Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and special Advisor to Twinza, for a discussion on investing for success in PNG.
  
 

  Looking back, Peter said "it was the initial investments in our downstream product solutions business, our talented Papua New Guinean workforce, and collaboration with our important stakeholders, that enabled our eventual move into upstream development.” 
  
  “The PNG LNG Project has already unlocked significant value for the country, and has set the stage for a potential new series of investments in the coming decades. PNG could be on the verge of a new era of economic growth. Just imagine the potential of what can be delivered for the Papua New Guinean people if the next wave of projects move forward," he concluded. #PNGpartnership #PNGLNG

post_body_text:
“Now more than ever, PNG needs a strong business community to help the nation strengthen its economy and build a better life for all Papua New Guineans,” shared Peter Larden, American Chamber of Commerce Coral Sea (AmCham Coral Sea) President and ExxonMobil PNG Managing Director. 
  
 

  Addressing guests at the AmCham Coral Sea’s Young PNG Business Leaders event in Port Moresby, Peter encouraged the next generation of Papua New Guineans to become responsible business leaders and roles models to help drive the country’s economy forward.
  
 

  “Young business leaders are laying the foundation for PNG’s future; they are nation builders.
  
 

  “Developing business relationships offers more than just financial opportunity. When businesses come together, they create a broader set of value.
  
 

  “I am a firm believer in the good that business brings to PNG, and I encourage all young business leaders to foster new relationships that helps them grow in business and in life,” Peter concluded. #PNGpartnership #PNGLNG
  .
  .
  .
  Image courtesy of CIPE.

post_body_text:
“The training that ExxonMobil PNG (EMPNG) provides is world class. You are given a roadmap from the outset and know exactly what training programs you need to attend to achieve specific competencies,” said Peter Pomeleu, #PNGLNG Plant Surveillance Engineering Lead.
  
 

  Joining EMPNG in 2011 as part of the first intake of the Graduate Engineering Program, Peter has grown his career from an early assignment with Esso Australia as a Machinery Engineer to becoming the first Papua New Guinean LNG Plant Surveillance Engineering Lead with EMPNG.
  
 

  “It has been great to travel overseas for some training elements because it has given me the chance to meet with the broader ExxonMobil engineering community and learn best practice processes.”
  
 

  Throughout his career, Peter says EMPNG’s face-to-face and online training programs, as well as mentoring by his colleagues, have made him feel supported. 
  
 

  “EMPNG provides the structure, guidance and support that you need, so the onus is on you to make the most of it and progress your career. 
  
 

  “The training and support I have received has given me the ability to work anywhere in the world. What I love most about the training curriculum is that it is based on real-life work scenarios, which allows us to apply newly-acquired skills into the field straight away,” he concluded. #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
Across Papua New Guinea, cane toads are an invasive species that impact local wildlife, including causing the population decline of predator species that are poisoned when eating the toad. 
  
 

  To help educate #PNGLNG Upstream area communities about the effect cane toads can have on the environment, our team developed an innovative awareness talking poster. 
  
 

  Featuring audio recordings in three different languages: English, Tok Pisin and Huli, the poster is activated and narrates the text when red buttons are pressed. 
  
 

  The talking poster is just one aspect of our approach to managing the cane toad population and helping prevent colonies from establishing. #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
“ExxonMobil PNG is a great place to work. The company is focused on advancing PNG citizens and promoting high levels of safety, integrity and professionalism,” shared Rosinta Lakasa, IT Technical Professional at ExxonMobil PNG (EMPNG). 
  
 

  “EMPNG supports our personal growth and development through training as well as encouraging involvement of staff in community volunteer activities."
  
 

  Based at the #PNGLNG Plant outside Port Moresby, Rosinta’s role involves maintaining the health and reliability of ExxonMobil’s network and IT infrastructure as well as constantly looking for opportunities to optimise and improve our business.
  
 

  “It is a very challenging role with lots of responsibility working alongside the Plant site leadership team.
  
 

  “Every day is interesting. I get to work with an amazing team of skilled professionals who all support and care for each other. We are driven by a common purpose and our motto of ‘Nobody Gets Hurt’.”
  
 

  Since joining EMPNG, Rosinta has implemented multiple IT initiatives including digital signage, audio visual upgrades, SharePoint site creation and support for large scale communications on site. 
  
 

  “Leveraging my previous experience in application development, I have also implemented many digital solutions to improve business safety and performance, especially during EMPNG’s response to COVID 19.”
  
 

  In ten years’ time Rosinta hopes to still be working for EMPNG, supporting the expansion of projects and mentoring young aspiring Papua New Guineans in their IT careers. 
  
 

  “Work hard and take every opportunity to grow. Whatever role you have now can be as big or as small as you make it. Take the opportunities and leverage the team around you to add value and make a difference,” concluded Rosinta. #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
“Being an employee of a company that is an industry innovator and leader in the energy business with a reputable safety culture is the best thing that has ever happened to my family and me,” shared Peter Kera, Land & Community Affairs Upstream Manager at ExxonMobil PNG (EMPNG). 
  
 

  Before joining EMPNG ten years ago, Peter worked for the Government of PNG with the Ministry of Communication and Information and prior to that with the Department of Education. 
  
 

  Based at Hides Gas Conditioning Plant, Peter leads a team of Land and Community Affairs professionals across the #PNGLNG Upstream area, including in Hela and Southern Highlands Provinces, managing relationships with the community and key external stakeholders to support EMPNG’s social investment program. 
  
 

  “It gives me a sense of satisfaction when I see the communities overwhelmed with joy and appreciation when we handover a community project, whether it be school classrooms, teacher’s houses or clinic renovations. That is the best part of my job, knowing we are giving back to the community.
  
 

  “I am proud to be part of a company that built its foundations on the safety of its workforce and the community within which it works. The company not only maintains high safety standards to protect its workforce and the communities where it operates but also focuses on upskilling and training Papua New Guineans. I am incredibly proud to be part of a company that is investing in our country.”
  
 

  Peter believes everyone can achieve great things in life if you have faith in yourself and overcome your fears. 
  
 

  “Believing in oneself is the foundation. Take that first step to face your fears in your life. The major fears in our lives are sometimes nothing but opportunity in disguise. When you are given the opportunity to lead, honour the privilege of leadership and the duty that comes with it,” concluded Peter. #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
“ExxonMobil PNG (EMPNG) is the first company I’ve worked with, and I think it will be where I make my long-term career as I love the culture and my wanwoks,” shared Fedro Gene, Productions Contracts Administrator at ExxonMobil PNG. 
  
 

  Joining EMPNG in 2010 as an intern with the logistics department, Fedro has progressed his career working with teams across the Maintenance Department, Operations Technical and Document Controls. 
  
 

  “ExxonMobil is so diverse and multi-cultural. One thing that brings us all together here in PNG is our six core values. One that stands out for me is Integrity and acting with honesty and fairness. This is critical to the role that I am in. The company is about responsible behaviour and adherence to strong moral and ethical principles.
  
 

  “The principles and values we learn and practice at work build our character and personality when off work, and that’s one thing I really appreciate. That is why this is a great opportunity for me. My job not only provides employment but also helps me in my personal life to become a better person in the community that I live in, and amongst my family and friends.”
  
 

  Looking back on his eleven years with the company, Fedro considers his time as the Information Management & Document Control Lead to be his highlight as it gave him an opportunity to travel to places like Singapore, Brisbane, Melbourne and the Gold Coast – prior to the onset of COVID-19. 
  
 

  “I am currently studying a Diploma in Management through Divine Word University’s Flexible Learning. After graduating, I hope to continue my studies to attain a Bachelor in Management and in ten years from now I want to progress up the ladder in my career with ExxonMobil.
  
 

  “If I was to give young people across PNG advice, it would be never give up if you are a school leaver like me. There will be times when you feel like you have it all figured out and under control and there will be times when you feel like you are lost and do not have control of your life. But one thing is for sure, you can either choose to embrace it and learn from these experiences or you can choose to rebel against life’s challenges, resenting every moment of your journey. 
  
 

  “You must always remember that the decisions we make in life will either rob us from our growth and development or give us the opportunity to learn from those challenges and become a better person for having experienced them,” concluded Fedro.

post_body_text:
In continued support of the National Control Centre (NCC), along with Provincial Health Authorities, ExxonMobil PNG on behalf of the #PNGLNG Project and its partners are overseeing the implementation of a PGK4.3 million COVID-19 response effort. 
  
 

  Since launching the program in early 2021, critical supplies and equipment have been delivered under the initiative to the National Capital District, Hela Province and Central Province, along with Port Moresby General Hospital and NCC operations. 
  
 

  Speaking about the program, David Manning, Police Commissioner and Controller of the PNG COVID-19 National Pandemic Response, said “ExxonMobil PNG and its PNG LNG Project partners are once again showing their commitment to Papua New Guinea. COVID-19 has had a significant impact on the PNG people and our economy, and it will take everyone – government, industry, international donors, and communities – to work together to overcome the pandemic’s many challenges.” 
  
 

  Read more about the COVID-19 response on the PNG LNG website here: https://bit.ly/3dNUTzd. #PNGpartnership

Since launching the program in early 2021, critical supplies and equipment have been delivered under the initiative to the National Capital District, Hela Province and Central Province, along with Port Moresby General Hospital and NCC operations. 

Speaking about the program, David Manning, Police Commissioner and Controller of the PNG COVID-19 National Pandemic Response, said “ExxonMobil PNG and its PNG LNG Project partners are once again showing their commitment to Papua New Guinea. COVID-19 has had a significant impact on the PNG people and our economy, and it will take everyone – government, industry, international donors, and communities – to work together to overcome the pandemic’s many challenges.” 

Read more about the COVID-19 response on the PNG LNG website here: https://bit.ly/3dNUTzd. #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
“It is a privilege to be working with a PNG company that specialises in non-destructive testing (NDT). 
  
 

  “It gives us an opportunity to work to world class standards in the field of NDT and enhance our learnings by working in collaboration with other engineers and technicians,” shared Nares Engineering Limited’s (NEL) Integrity Engineer (Mechanical Engineer), Ezekiel Dau. 
  
 

  Based at the Hides Gas Conditioning Plant, in Hela Province, supporting asset integrity and quality assurance of the facility, Ezekiel credits NEL for giving him the opportunity to work in an environment which is new and highly complex in-terms of technology and system with regard to LNG production.
  
 

  “This has continually improved our skills technically and learnings when working in a multi-cultural setting like this and amongst people who are highly skilled and qualified in their respective fields.
  
 

  “Each day, we start off with a safety meeting with the Maintenance team, then our own meeting with our ExxonMobil Integrity Supervisors for daily tasks. 
  
 

  “Afterwards, we prepare our work scope for the day, check our tools for calibration and for any faults, acquire gas testers for our equipment and tools for jobs to be completed in the live production plant”
  
 

  Ezekiel enjoys utilising different NDT techniques to locate defects and prevent failures from occurring that can be catastrophic in terms of production loss, environment, and safety to clients. 
  
 

  “One of my job highlights has been completing an NDT inspection for a client and locating cracking defects on the weld of a boiler tube. The boiler was not operating at a certain pressure that was required due to cracks causing leaks.
  
 

  “Ten years from now, God willing, I will make the most of every opportunity that comes my way, enhancing each technique in NDT, Condition Monitoring & Reliability Engineering,” concluded Ezekiel. #PNGpartnership #PNGLNG

post_body_text:
“I never thought in a million years while studying at university that I was going to be a Safety Specialist. My advice to any aspiring young person out there is… if an opportunity presents itself to you, take it! Do not hold yourself back and wonder whether you are qualified for it or not; just give your best and you will be surprised that you’re enjoying it,” shared Priscilla Peter, Safety Specialist at ExxonMobil PNG (EMPNG). 
  
 

  Based at ExxonMobil Haus in Port Moresby, Priscilla coordinates ExxonMobil Haus safety programs and facilitate the Safety Committee activities.
  
 

  “I support EMPNG worksites by performing regular analysis of their safety data and drive the roll-out of our Safe Choice program in-country. I also serve as the Ergonomics Lead Site Administrator, leading a team of 42 Ergo contacts spread across the business. Another key component of my role is the oversight of Vector Control for our worksites. Vector Control activities are associated with the eradication or limitation of disease carrying insects or animals such as mosquitoes (malaria).” 
  
 

  In her role, Priscilla has the opportunity to engage with different professionals from various backgrounds.
  
 

  “I am amazed at how personal safety plays a vital role in every aspect of the jobs we do, whether it be sitting in the office or working out in the field. With the extensive safety data collection that EMPNG has, we are able to pick up trends and identify areas where accidents and incidents are prone to happen to mitigate hazards and ensure ‘Nobody Gets Hurt’. The highlight for me was providing safety support to the rate reduction activities at the LNG Plant this year. Rate reduction is a partial shutdown so that maintenance can be done on machines that are offline. It was a great feeling to be part of that effort.
  
 

  In ten years, I see myself in a leadership role within EMPNG, mentoring and guiding the upcoming young Papua New Guineans,” concluded Priscilla. #PNGpartnership #PNGLNG

post_body_text:
On behalf of ExxonMobil PNG (EMPNG) and the #PNGLNG Project, we are excited to welcome Peter Larden as Managing Director. 
  
 

  Peter re-joins the PNG LNG Project having been part of the of the early construction phase in 2009/2010. Returning to Papua New Guinea, Peter and his wife Taryn bring fond memories of their time here, from the wonderful people to the beautiful country and rich culture.  
  
 

  Reflecting on his return, Peter said “over the past several years I’ve watched ExxonMobil PNG from afar and have been amazed at not only what has been achieved but how the team has achieved it. 
  
 

  “While it is hard to narrow down the highlights, seeing the initial project commissioning and production ramp up well ahead of schedule, to proudly building a strong Papua New Guinean workforce, to developing local suppliers and supporting landowner companies, to supporting the communities in which we operate, to navigating the challenges of COVID-19, and all of this while continuing to improve ExxonMobil PNG’s safety and environmental performance. 
  
 

  “These are truly amazing achievements and I am proud and humbled to be taking over from Andrew Barry to lead this incredible and high performing team. I look forward to continuing to share the #PNGLNG story and the critical importance of National Content in everything we do.” 
  
 

  Joining ExxonMobil in 2005, Peter has previously worked across projects in Australia, the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom and Africa. 
  
 

  Both Peter and his family are thrilled to be back in Paua New Guinea and are excited to be part of the #PNGLNG community. #PNGpartnership

post_body_text:
Snakes are an important part of Papua New Guinea’s biodiversity and play a crucial role in balancing the ecosystem. We celebrated #worldenvironmentday on Saturday 5 June by catching up with #PNGLNG resident snake handler Owen Paiva, who safely removes snakes from the LNG Plant (LNGP) and relocates them to similar environments away from people and local communities.
  
  “The environment we live in always has a balance in place where living things play specific roles and depend on each other – this is ecology. When a component of that balance is affected, it can cause a shift to all that rely on it,” shared Owen. 
  
  Since 2004, Owen has been involved in snakebite research and safely handling venomous snakes. Before joining International SOS (ISOS) and working at the LNG Plant, he managed a NGO-based snakebite and venom research laboratory – the Charles Campbell Toxinology Centre (CCTC). 
  
  “Many snakes feed on rodents, lizards and even other snakes, while other snakes feed on frogs, and some on aquatic animals. Some birds like eagles, kookaburras, and owls depend on snakes for their diet. If the number of snakes decreases in an environment then the population of rodents and lizards may increase, and birds and other species that depend on snakes as food may also suffer. Snakes have their part to play in maintaining this environmental balance.”
  
  Since joining ISOS last year and working at LNGP, Owen credits the zero number of snakebite incidents to ExxonMobil PNG’s strong safety protocols which are similar to those he practiced at CCTC – something Owen believes has contributed to never being bitten by a venomous snake in 15 years. 
  
  Communities neighbouring LNGP are home to 12 different species of snakes including Papuan taipan, whipsnakes, carpet pythons, amethystine pythons, olive pythons, slatey grey snakes, common tree snakes, brown tree snakes, mangrove snakes, blind snakes and sea kraits. 
  
  At ExxonMobil PNG we take protecting the environment very seriously. We remain committed to supporting a range of environmental initiatives and educating communities to help preserve Papua New Guinea’s natural wonders for generations to come. #PNGpartnership

Snakes have their part to play in maintaining this environmental balance.”
 
Since joining ISOS last year and working at LNGP, Owen credits the zero number of snakebite incidents to ExxonMobil PNG’s strong safety protocols which are similar to those he practiced at CCTC – something Owen believes has contributed to never being bitten by a venomous snake in 15 years.

Students at Bogi Literacy School, in Papa Village, received an exciting boost recently when staff from the LNG Plant visited the school to install new playground equipment on behalf of the #PNGLNG Project.
